qas.question: Who wrote 'A Vindication of the Rights of Men'?
Who said the Reflections were "the manifesto of a Counter Revolution"?
Who did Mackintosh compare Burke to?
What types of wisdom did Mackintosh say Burke had?
When did Mary Wollstonecraft publish her response?
What did Mackintosh claim he had more of than any other writer?
Who did Thomas Paine compare Burke to?

plausible_answers.text: the manifesto of a Counter Revolution

context: Burke's Reflections sparked a pamphlet war. <a0_0>Thomas Paine<a0_0/> penned the Rights of Man in <b5_0>1791<b5_0/> as a response to Burke; <a1_0>Mary Wollstonecraft<a1_0/> published A Vindication of the Rights of Men and <a2_0>James Mackintosh<a2_0/> wrote Vindiciae Gallicae. Mackintosh was the first to see the Reflections as "<b9_0>the manifesto of a Counter Revolution<b9_0/>". Mackintosh later agreed with Burke's views, remarking in <b6_0>December 1796<b6_0/> after meeting him, that Burke was "minutely and accurately informed, to a wonderful exactness, with respect to every fact relating to the French Revolution". Mackintosh later said: "Burke was one of the first thinkers as well as one of the greatest orators of his time. He is without parallel in any age, excepting perhaps <a3_0><b8_0>Lord Bacon and Cicero<b8_0/><a3_0/>; and his works contain an ampler store of <a4_0><b7_0>political and moral<a4_0/> wisdom<b7_0/> than can be found in any other writer whatever".
